newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Easing ban, Taiwan to let China ships sail strait.
newsitem.headline: Easing ban, Taiwan to let China ships sail strait.

text.p: Taiwan said it issued approvals on Friday allowing four shippers from arch rival China to sail directly across the Taiwan strait, ending a ban dating to 1949.

"Kaohsiung port has approved four mainland shippers. They can start whenever they are ready," Teng You-yi, an official of the southern Taiwan port who signed the documents, told Reuters by telephone minutes after the signing.

The approvals eliminated the final hurdle to the first direct sailings of the Taiwan strait in 48 years, although Nationalist-ruled Taiwan, deeply wary of communist China, has put restrictions in place forbidding direct cargo exchanges.

Although mainland cargoes shipped from the Fujian ports of Xiamen or Fuzhou can be brought into Kaohsiung port, they can only be processed for onward shipment to third countries and will not be allowed to enter Taiwan customs, officials said.
Likewise, Taiwan cargoes at Kaohsiung cannot be put directly aboard vessels that will cross directly to Xiamen or Fuzhou.
Teng was careful to play down the significance of the development, saying Taiwan was allowing only transshipments and not direct cargo exchanges between Taiwan and China.
"This is only for transshipments at Kaohsiung's offshore transshipment centre and is not direct links," Teng said.
The mainland shippers approved are Fujian Foreign Trade Centre Shipping Co, Fujian Provincial Shipping Co, Fujian Xiamen Shipping Co and Shamen Ocean Shipping Co, Teng said.
